parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions are available to encourage natural foraging behaviours in captive primates.
[Statement 2]: Providing live invertebrates reduced inactivity in captive loris.
[Statement 3]: Providing live invertebrates increased foraging in captive loris to levels seen in wild loris.
[Statement 4]: Providing cut branches allows captive gorillas to use the same processing skills as wild gorillas to forage.
[Statement 5]: Live vegetation in planters for foraging increased time spent foraging in chimpanzees compared to normal browse and grass.
[Statement 6]: Changing feeding times to unpredictable schedules decreased inactivity in chimpanzees.
[Statement 7]: Feeding individuals in social groups allows monkeys to complete enrichment tasks faster than when feeding alone.
[Statement 8]: Feeding individuals in social groups encourages monkeys to eat more unfamiliar foods.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions are available to encourage natural foraging behaviours in captive primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Complex feeding devices have both beneficial and negative impacts on captive primates and carnivores.
[Statement 2]: For primates, puzzle feeders decreased food sharing.
[Statement 3]: For primates, puzzle feeders increased foraging behavior and tool use.
[Statement 4]: Puzzle feeders also increased aggression levels in some primates.
[Statement 5]: Puzzle feeders increased the time primates spent feeding.
[Statement 6]: Puzzle feeders reduced inactive time in primates.
[Statement 7]: For carnivores, prey simulation devices including lures, pulleys and bungees increased activity levels and behavioral diversity in felids.
[Statement 8]: Prey simulation devices decreased pacing behavior in cougars.
[Statement 9]: Prey simulation devices increased walking in cougars.
[Statement 10]: Tigers initially showed increased pacing when presented with carcasses on bungees.
[Statement 11]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased exploratory behaviors in various primate species, including chimpanzees and lemurs.
[Statement 12]: Scattering food throughout enclosures reduced abnormal behaviors and aggression in various primate species, including chimpanzees and lemurs.
[Statement 13]: Providing frozen food in ice decreased stereotypic behaviors in bears and felids.
[Statement 14]: Providing frozen food in ice increased activity levels in bears and felids.
[Statement 15]: Complex feeding interventions appear to generally enhance natural foraging behaviors.
[Statement 16]: Complex feeding interventions appear to generally reduce inactivity.
[Statement 17]: Some implementations of complex feeding interventions may initially increase stress behaviors like pacing or aggression in certain individuals.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the potential benefits and negative impacts of using complex feeding devices, like puzzle feeders or prey simulators, for captive primates and carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Research on altering feeding schedules in zoo environments shows several documented effects.
[Statement 2]: When chimpanzees were fed on unpredictable schedules, the chimpanzees' inactivity decreased.
[Statement 3]: Random temporal feeding reduced stereotypic pacing behaviors in tigers and cheetahs.
[Statement 4]: Unpredictable schedules increased behavioral diversity in red foxes.
[Statement 5]: Unpredictable schedules increased alertness in black-footed cats.
[Statement 6]: The effects of altering feeding schedules vary by species.
[Statement 7]: Unpredictable feeding increased territorial behavior in coyotes.
[Statement 8]: Unpredictable feeding did not affect traveling or foraging in coyotes.
[Statement 9]: Large felids fed once every three days paced more frequently on non-feeding days.
[Statement 10]: Presenting feeds during different crowd levels also showed effects on animal behavior.
[Statement 11]: Chimpanzees increased foraging when smaller crowds were present.
[Statement 12]: Chimpanzees increased object use when smaller crowds were present.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In a zoo environment, what are the documented effects of altering the timing and predictability of feeding schedules for captive primates and carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Presenting whole foods instead of processed items is an alternative to processed or commercial pellet diets for captive primates.
[Statement 2]: Providing fresh produce is an alternative to processed or commercial pellet diets for captive primates.
[Statement 3]: Offering cut branches, also known as browse, is an alternative to processed or commercial pellet diets for captive primates.
[Statement 4]: Feeding whole carcasses with or without organs is an alternative diet for captive carnivores.
[Statement 5]: Providing live vertebrate prey is an alternative diet for captive carnivores.
[Statement 6]: Feeding plant-derived protein diets is an alternative diet for captive carnivores.
[Statement 7]: Allocating fast days is an alternative feeding strategy for captive carnivores.
[Statement 8]: Increasing food variety is an alternative feeding strategy for captive carnivores.
[Statement 9]: Alternatives to processed diets can increase feeding time for captive animals.
[Statement 10]: Alternatives to processed diets can reduce pacing behaviors in captive animals.
[Statement 11]: Alternatives to processed diets can provide better nutritional profiles in some species.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the alternatives to feeding processed or commercial pellet diets to captive primates and carnivores?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What dietary modifications are available to better reflect the natural feeding ecology of captive primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several dietary modifications are available to better reflect the natural feeding ecology of captive primates.
[Statement 2]: Providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased feeding time in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 3]: Providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed reduced inactivity in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 4]: Presenting food items whole rather than processed increased consumption in macaques.
[Statement 5]: Presenting food items whole rather than processed increased feeding time in macaques.
[Statement 6]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods, including removing domestic fruits, decreased regurgitation and reingestion in gorillas.
[Statement 7]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods, including removing domestic fruits, reduced aggression and self-directed behavior in lemurs.
[Statement 8]: Providing cut branches (browse) allowed captive gorillas to use the same processing skills as wild gorillas when foraging on stinging nettles.
[Statement 9]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased feeding and exploratory behaviors across multiple primate species including rhesus macaques, chimpanzees, lemurs, and gorillas.
[Statement 10]: Scattering food throughout enclosures reduced abnormal behaviors and aggression across multiple primate species including rhesus macaques, chimpanzees, lemurs, and gorillas.
[Statement 11]: Hiding food in containers combined with browse increased activity levels in lemurs and gibbons.
[Statement 12]: Hiding food in containers combined with browse increased foraging behaviors in lemurs and gibbons.
[Statement 13]: Providing live vegetation in planters led chimpanzees to spend more time foraging compared to normal feeding methods.
[Statement 14]: No evidence was captured regarding the effectiveness of providing food at natural wild feeding times.
[Statement 15]: No evidence was captured regarding the effectiveness of seasonal ingredient modification.
[Statement 16]: No evidence was captured regarding the effectiveness of nectar provision.
[Statement 17]: No evidence was captured regarding the effectiveness of continuous food access.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Within captive breeding programs for amphibians, what are the non-hormonal alternatives for simulating a breeding season to encourage reproduction?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Non-hormonal alternatives for simulating breeding seasons in amphibian captive breeding programs include environmental manipulation techniques.
[Statement 2]: Temperature variation is used to simulate amphibian breeding seasons, with one study showing breeding occurred following a temperature drop from 20-24°C to 17°C.
[Statement 3]: Artificial rainfall simulation has proven to be an effective method for encouraging amphibian reproduction.
[Statement 4]: Studies have demonstrated that simulating wet and dry seasons stimulated breeding and egg deposition in amphibians.
[Statement 5]: Lighting variation is an approach used to simulate seasonal changes for amphibians.
[Statement 6]: Lighting variation can involve changes in UV percentage or gradients to simulate seasonal light changes.
[Statement 7]: One study found no difference in amphibian clutch size from UV boost treatments.
[Statement 8]: Pre-breeding cooling periods have been shown to increase breeding success in amphibians.
[Statement 9]: Allowing female amphibians to gain weight before breeding can increase breeding success.
[Statement 10]: Separating amphibian sexes during non-breeding periods has been shown to increase breeding success.
[Statement 11]: Providing mate choice for amphibians can increase breeding success.
[Statement 12]: Playing recorded mating calls has been shown to increase amphibian breeding success.
[Statement 13]: Enclosure modifications can support amphibian breeding behavior.
[Statement 14]: Providing multiple egg laying sites, calling sites, and breeding areas within an enclosure supports breeding behavior.
[Statement 15]: Providing various substrates, including rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes, supports amphibian breeding behavior.

[Statement 1]: Several feeding-related interventions have been shown to reduce aggression among primates housed in social groups.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure is the most effective intervention for reducing aggression among primates housed in social groups.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 4]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 5]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced abnormal behaviors in chimpanzees.
[Statement 6]: Formulating a fruit-free diet that reflects the nutritional composition of wild foods reduced aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 7]: The use of puzzle feeders showed mixed results for reducing aggression in primates.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found that the use of puzzle feeders decreased food sharing among primates.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found that the use of puzzle feeders increased tool use among primates.
[Statement 10]: The use of puzzle feeders also resulted in increased aggression among primates.
[Statement 11]: Feeding individual primates separately has shown no evidence of effectiveness in reducing aggression.
[Statement 12]: Changing the number of feeds per day increased feeding time in chimpanzees.
[Statement 13]: Changing the number of feeds per day increased hair eating in baboons.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__To reduce aggression among primates housed in social groups, what are the most effective feeding-related interventions?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Research shows that several dietary modifications effectively encourage naturalistic behaviors in captive lemurs and macaques.
[Statement 2]: For lemurs, a fruit-free diet was found to reduce aggression and self-directed behavior.
[Statement 3]: Lemurs and macaques benefit from scattered feeding throughout their enclosure.
[Statement 4]: Scattered feeding increases exploratory and feeding behaviors in lemurs and macaques.
[Statement 5]: Scattered feeding reduces abnormal behaviors and aggression in lemurs and macaques.
[Statement 6]: Presenting whole foods instead of processed items increases food consumption in macaques.
[Statement 7]: Presenting whole foods instead of processed items increases feeding time in macaques.
[Statement 8]: Providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed results in more time spent feeding in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 9]: Providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed results in less inactive time in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 10]: The inclusion of cut branches allows for natural processing skills in captive primates.
[Statement 11]: Captive gorillas used the same techniques as wild gorillas to handle stinging nettles.
[Statement 12]: Live vegetation in planters can enhance foraging behavior.
[Statement 13]: Chimpanzees spent more time foraging when provided with planted grass.
[Statement 14]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods represents a comprehensive approach to dietary naturalism in captive primates.
[Statement 15]: The removal of domestic fruits is part of a comprehensive approach to dietary naturalism in captive primates.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__For captive lemurs and macaques, what are the most beneficial dietary changes to encourage naturalistic behaviours?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several social feeding strategies for captive primates show distinct trade-offs.
[Statement 2]: Social group feeding appears to enhance feeding efficiency.
[Statement 3]: Monkeys complete enrichment tasks faster when in social groups versus feeding alone.
[Statement 4]: Social group feeding encourages dietary exploration, as monkeys consumed more unfamiliar foods when in the presence of their groupmates.
[Statement 5]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduces aggression and abnormal behaviors in multiple primate species including rhesus macaques, chimpanzees, lemurs, and gorillas.
[Statement 6]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increases natural foraging behaviors in multiple primate species including rhesus macaques, chimpanzees, lemurs, and gorillas.
[Statement 7]: Feeding in the presence of smaller crowds increases natural foraging and object use behaviors in chimpanzees.
[Statement 8]: Separate individual feeding and subgroup feeding have not been systematically studied.
[Statement 9]: The trade-offs of separate individual feeding and subgroup feeding are undocumented.
[Statement 10]: The choice of feeding strategy appears to significantly impact both behavioral welfare and social dynamics of captive primates.
[Statement 11]: Social feeding generally promotes more efficient feeding and food exploration.
[Statement 12]: Distributed feeding approaches like scattering appear to reduce competition-related problems.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the trade-offs associated with different social feeding strategies for captive primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several dietary management strategies have been shown to reduce aggression and abnormal behaviors in captive primates.
[Statement 2]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods, including the removal of domestic fruits, resulted in lower aggression and self-directed behavior in lemurs.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 4]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced abnormal behaviors in chimpanzees.
[Statement 5]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure decreased aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 6]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased foraging behavior and activity levels in gorillas.
[Statement 7]: Providing cut branches (browse) allowed captive gorillas to use the same processing skills as wild gorillas when foraging with stinging nettles.
[Statement 8]: Changing the number of feeds per day for captive primates showed mixed results.
[Statement 9]: Changing the number of feeds per day resulted in increased feeding time in chimpanzees.
[Statement 10]: Changing the number of feeds per day resulted in increased hair eating in baboons.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What dietary management strategies are available for captive primates to reduce aggression and abnormal behaviours?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: For carnivores, providing food on random temporal schedules showed several benefits.
[Statement 2]: Random temporal feeding schedules reduced stereotypic pacing behaviors in tigers and cheetahs.
[Statement 3]: Random temporal feeding schedules increased behavioral diversity in red foxes.
[Statement 4]: Random temporal feeding schedules increased alertness in black-footed cats.
[Statement 5]: Unpredictable feeding increased territorial behavior in coyotes.
[Statement 6]: Unpredictable feeding did not affect traveling or foraging behaviors in coyotes.
[Statement 7]: For primates, one controlled study found that chimpanzees fed on unpredictable schedules showed decreased inactivity.
[Statement 8]: No evidence was found regarding visitor activity-based feeding schedules.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In a zoo setting, what are the potential benefits and harms of creating unpredictable feeding schedules for primates and carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Research shows several food-based enrichment strategies are effective for increasing activity and reducing pacing in captive felids.
[Statement 2]: Hiding food around enclosures was found to significantly increase exploring and foraging behaviours in leopard cats and black bears.
[Statement 3]: Hiding food around enclosures was found to decrease stereotypical pacing in leopard cats and black bears.
[Statement 4]: Hiding food around enclosures was found to reduce daytime sleeping in Canadian lynx.
[Statement 5]: Providing food on a random temporal schedule reduced stereotypic pacing behaviors in tigers and cheetahs.
[Statement 6]: Providing food on a random temporal schedule increased behavioral diversity in red foxes.
[Statement 7]: Providing food on a random temporal schedule increased alertness in black-footed cats.
[Statement 8]: Using devices to simulate live prey, including lure and pulley systems, increased activity levels and behavioral diversity in felids.
[Statement 9]: Tigers initially showed increased pacing when lure and pulley systems were used, before the tigers' behavior improved.
[Statement 10]: Presenting food frozen in ice decreased abnormal or stereotypic behaviors in felids.
[Statement 11]: Presenting food frozen in ice increased activity levels in felids.
[Statement 12]: Presenting food inside objects like Boomer balls increased exploratory behaviors in bears.
[Statement 13]: Presenting food inside objects like Boomer balls decreased stereotypic behaviors in bears.
[Statement 14]: Allocating fast days was found to increase pacing behavior in large felids on non-feeding days.
[Statement 15]: Allocating fast days is counterproductive for reducing stereotypic behaviors in large felids.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__For captive felids in zoos, which food-based enrichment strategies are most effective for increasing activity levels and reducing pacing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from primate studies shows several effective food presentation methods for increasing foraging behaviours in captive lemurs and macaques.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased feeding and exploratory behaviours in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout enclosures reduced aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 4]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased foraging activity.
[Statement 5]: Presenting whole foods instead of chopped foods increased both consumption and time spent feeding in macaques.
[Statement 6]: Hiding food in containers such as boxes and bags, particularly when combined with browse items, increased foraging behaviours and activity levels in lemurs.
[Statement 7]: Providing cut branches (browse) enabled captive gorillas to demonstrate natural processing skills similar to wild counterparts.
[Statement 8]: Puzzle feeders increased foraging time and reduced inactive time.
[Statement 9]: Puzzle feeders also increased aggression in some cases.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__For captive lemurs and macaques in a zoo setting, what methods of food presentation can increase foraging behaviours?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the known benefits and harms of using feeding devices that simulate prey or require manipulation for captive carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Feeding devices that simulate prey have both benefits and potential concerns for captive carnivores.
[Statement 2]: Activity levels increased in felids when the felids were presented with lure or pulley systems.
[Statement 3]: Behavioral diversity increased in felids with prey simulation devices.
[Statement 4]: Pacing behavior decreased in cougars provided with a carcass on a bungee.
[Statement 5]: Walking increased in cougars provided with a carcass on a bungee.
[Statement 6]: Altering food location around enclosures decreased pacing behaviors in cheetahs.
[Statement 7]: Pacing behavior initially increased in tigers when the tigers were provided with a carcass on a bungee device.
[Statement 8]: No evidence was captured for the effects of using automated feeders on captive carnivores.
[Statement 9]: No evidence was captured for the effects of presenting food in water on captive carnivores.
[Statement 10]: The lack of evidence for the effects of automated feeders or presenting food in water on captive carnivores indicates these approaches are either understudied or have not shown clear beneficial or harmful effects.
[Statement 11]: Prey-simulating feeding devices can provide behavioral benefits by reducing stereotypic pacing.
[Statement 12]: Prey-simulating feeding devices can provide behavioral benefits by increasing natural activity patterns.
[Statement 13]: Responses to prey-simulating feeding devices may vary by species.
[Statement 14]: Some tigers showed an initial increase in pacing before potential adaptation to prey-simulating feeding devices.

[Statement 1]: Beyond dietary changes, several environmental and social husbandry actions can promote amphibian breeding success in captive settings.
[Statement 2]: Providing specific enclosure furniture such as rotting logs, hollow bamboo pipes, and varied substrates can create calling sites and breeding areas.
[Statement 3]: Simulating seasonal changes through temperature variation by dropping temperatures from 20-24°C to 17°C has been shown to stimulate breeding.
[Statement 4]: Varying artificial rainfall to simulate wet and dry seasons has been shown to stimulate breeding.
[Statement 5]: Allowing female mate choice is an effective strategy for managing amphibian social dynamics.
[Statement 6]: Separating sexes during non-breeding periods is an effective strategy for managing amphibian social dynamics.
[Statement 7]: Playing recorded breeding calls to simulate the breeding season is an effective strategy for managing amphibian social dynamics.
[Statement 8]: Using surrogate species to refine husbandry techniques before working with target critically endangered species has proven beneficial.
[Statement 9]: Hormonal treatments can be used to induce sperm and egg release in amphibians.
[Statement 10]: Following hormonal treatment, 30-71% of females produce viable eggs.
[Statement 11]: A combined approach incorporating multiple factors has shown increased breeding success and larger clutch sizes.
[Statement 12]: A combined approach for breeding success can include pre-breeding cooling periods and allowing females to gain weight before breeding.
[Statement 13]: A combined approach for breeding success can include providing mate choice and playing recorded calls.
[Statement 14]: A combined approach for breeding success can include using enclosures with proper furniture and flowing water.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Beyond dietary changes, what alternative husbandry actions can be taken in a captive setting to promote amphibian breeding success?
